item.question: In which conversation does the Cebuano speaker say, "Nice to meet you?"
item.hint: The soldier states his name in both conversations, but only in one does the Cebuano speaker offer a direct reply to his introduction.
item.feedback: Correct. In this conversation, the Cebuano speaker says, Gikalipay ko ang pag-ilaila kanimo. (Nice to meet you.)

item.question: In which conversation does the soldier seek an interpreter?
item.feedback: Correct. In this conversation, the soldier asks, Asa na man ang taghubad? (Where is the interpreter?)

item.question: In which conversation does the soldier thank the Cebuano speaker?
item.hint: The Cebuano term for Thank you is Salamat.
item.feedback: Correct. In this conversation, the soldier says Salamat (Thank you) when the Cebuano speaker asks him into his home.

item.question: In which conversation does the soldier say, "Excuse me?"
item.hint: In one of these conversations, the soldier says Excuse me when taking leave of the Cebuano speaker.
item.feedback: Correct. In this conversation, the soldier says, Pasayloa (Excuse me) before parting ways with the Cebuano speaker.

item.question: In which conversation does the soldier ask the same question twice?
item.hint: In one of these conversations, the soldier uses the same follow-up question while seeking to identify two individuals.
item.feedback: Correct. In this conversation, the soldier asks, Sigurado ka? (Are you sure?) to confirm the Cebuano speaker's statements.
